div.p: Today, the Ramallah dialect shares many features with other urban centres of the region and shows only few traces of the original rural Palestinian variety.

Ramallah is a city in the West Bank and the administrative centre of the Palestinian Authority. Originally a predominantly Christian town, it has merged with neighbouring al-Bireh, which is predominantly Muslim, to form the municipality of Ramallah–al-Bireh. Most often, al-Bireh is subsumed when speaking of Ramallah.

Today, Ramallah’s population is mostly Sunni Muslim, also due to an increase in population and the opening of refugee camps since 1948. The city has urban characteristic such as a social heterogeneity of the population, despite the population being little over 60,000 people, and boasts a middle class that is part of a globalist, modernist élite.

Ramallah’s Christian identity is stressed despite the fact that the majority of its population is actually Muslim, and restaurants can obtain alcohol licenses there, but not in adjacent al-Bireh. Christians are believed to be less socially conservative, and Ramallah’s Christian character is invoked to explain the lack of social conservativism, an explanation not fully in line with the facts.
Because of its sunny and mild climate, it used to be a popular summer resort and wealthy citizens and tourists built houses there.

Seeger (dialect-)geographically locates Ramallah as a part of Jabal al-Quds, an Ottoman district that did not belong to a specific tribe. The old in Ramallah and al-Bireh stress that they are not affiliated to any “Banī Fulān”, i.e. they are not part of any tribe.

Even though it is historically a rural community, today an urban dialect is spoken in Ramallah. This is attributed to people from Lidd and Ramle moving to Ramallah in 1948, when the State of Israel was founded and many Arabs were forced to leave their homes. The deeper layers of dialect in Ramallah are probably similar to the dialects of the villages surrounding it. One of the distinctive features of the urban type is the final Imāla of the feminine ending (-a > -e). The pronominal suffix 3rd person sing. masc. is -e in Ramallah, but not raised in the villages (e.g. bēte “his house” in Ramallah, but bēta in the villages). According to Seeger 2009, this could be a remainder of a communal Christian dialect in the area. Interesting is the personal pronoun 3rd pers. pl. in Ramallah: Seeger 2009 describes hinne only for Ramallah, but not al-Bireh. This pronoun, different from MSA hum (masc.) / hunna (fem.) is shared with many Syrian and Lebanese dialects.
The process of linguistic levelling is sped up the youth’s preference for urban prestige varieties. The contact with Hebrew speakers is marginal in Ramallah, and loans play a very limited role.

A pioneering work on the Palestinian dialects, urban and rural, is Bauer 1926. A dissertation by Abu Nahleh 1985 deals with object clitics and pronouns in the Ramallah dialect. Cadora 1992 examines the process of urbanization in Ramallah and how it affects the speech of its inhabitants.

The rural dialects of the central West Bank are described in much detail by Seeger 2009, Shachmon 2011, Shachmon 2013a, Shachmon 2013b, and Shachmon 2018, as well as Shachmon 2021 but conclusions about Ramallah itself can only be drawn by contrast. The dialect substrate of the city, however, is certainly similar to the dialects of the surrounding villages.

Bauer’s 1957 is still a helpful source for Palestinian Colloquial (Arabic-German). Barthélemy with the supplement by Denizeau is unparalleled as a dictionary of the colloquial of the area. Al-Barghuti is an Arabic-Arabic dictionary, whereas Elihai 1973 and Elihai 2004 are an Arabic-French and a learner’s dictionary, respectively.

There are no textbooks dealing with the dialect of Ramallah specifically, but a good learner’s resource is Halloun and Seeger 2001 (German-Arabic) with a second volume published in 2006, which is sensitive to dialectal differences. Seeger 2013 is a textbook on urban Palestinian Arabic. Elihai 2011 is a classic for learners of Palestinan Arabic (English-Arabic).
